Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2020
Data:
There are so many purifiers out there, and it's difficult to make a decision. This one is the best bet for the cost, can clean a fairly large space, and can capture particles even finer than most other purifiers available. Yes, there are better units available, but they're going to cost at least twice as much. This unit outperforms everything else in its price point.

It is very quiet. There are a few reviews of people complaining about the noise level. The lowest two settings are barely noticeable. The highest two settings are louder, but it's the whoosh of the volume of air that it's moving. The noise is not mechanical or that of fan blades, it's purely the air noise. You can't change physics. Don't know what these people are on about. Honestly, I'm glad that it is able to move so much air that you can hear it; but you don't need to run it on high or turbo for long amounts of time, anyway.
Filter costs are very reasonable - you will spend about $140 a year. A lot of people are sticker shocked by filter costs, but these are an amazing value when put against the competition.
When I ran this for the first time, I left it on turbo for about an hour. All odors in the house were completely gone. The smell, if there is one, from the purified air would be best described as fresh, perhaps faintly sweet.
It's well made, and when coupled with high-end filtration in your central air system, it will keep your house clean and fresh.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2019
Data:
Bought this to try and clean out an apartment unit that was absolutely pungent with second/third hand cigarette smoke from the neighbor. What pulled me in was the promise of the large treatable area (over 1000 sq ft) and the ultra HEPA filter that filters particles smaller than usual - small enough to filter smoke particles. With that and the ionizing feature and the coconut carbon filter, I thought I'd be set.
Upon setting up the purifier in the unit's living room, I, like a few others, noticed a plastic-y smell the first time I turned it (and a second unit I also tested) on...but it went away within a day. I was going to leave it on "Auto" mode but the air quality light went from red to blue in less than two minutes (turning the fan on the lowest setting)...even though the place was clearly contaminated with who-knows-what from the smoke seeping in...so I manually left it on high. The entire apartment unit is only ~850 sq ft, so I expected it to be able to filter everything...and it definitely helped...but I just didn't get the quality I was expecting. The unit still smelled pretty bad upon entering, and I couldn't stand to be in it for more than about 40 minutes before feeling ill (which is a big improvement over not being able to stand it for 10 minutes previously).
So I thought, okay, maybe the space is just too open and/or the contaminant (which renews itself quite frequently) is just too strong. So I gave up and put it in the bedroom, which is no more than 300 sq ft, but also along the wall shared with the smoking neighbor. Left there for two days on the second highest setting and with the ionizer on...it completely transformed that room and its closet into a livable space. I was astounded. My clothes, which previously reeked of cigarette smoke, actually went back to smelling good...no trace of smoke at all. It was amazing. There is now, at least, one room in the apartment where I can breathe without complications.
Unfortunately, I don't have the funds to dish out for 2-3 more of these to fill the apartment unit with, so I'll likely be keeping one of these and returning the other (and moving out!). Though, speaking of funds, you can find these off Amazon for almost half the price advertised on the AirDoctor website if you just search around a bit.

Data: Cleans air but at the expense of your health. Do not use it in a bedroom. Through digging in deeper with the research on purifiers I found out they create negatively charged oxygen ions that attract dust, dirt, and mold from the air, which later stick to surfaces. Your lungs and throat being two of them. It doesn’t purify air, it just moves the containment’s to a different place. You’ll notice white smudge on black surfaces (and “black wall effect”). As good as it sounded, the health effects to my throat and lungs are not worth the change in odor. I woke up with headaches constantly, which dragged on until the evening. It took me sleeping somewhere else to finally realize what was going on. Goes to show you, you can’t just magically change the environment of your home with a product from Amazon. I did hear mechanical filters with none of this harmful/advanced technology is okay, but I would recommend staying away from all of it.

Data:
UPDATE: Extended attached 99.97% graph to include AirDoctor data point. It's worse than I thought.
The manufacturer states "UltraHEPA FILTER removes 99.95% of particles as small as .003 microns."
I can't find any specification for "UltraHEPA."
The common standard for HEPA filters specifies the filtration efficiency at the "most penetrating particle size" (MPPS) which is lower than for particles SMALLER or LARGER. A 99.97% filter has a MPPS of about 0.2 microns; it has a >99% filtration efficiency at 0.01 microns.
AIRDOCTOR should stick to a common specification so intelligent comparisons could be made, or at least demonstrate their filtration efficiency at the common index point (MPPS) for filters which adhere to accepted standards. As it stands, I think the AirDoctor filter is probably overpriced.
GlobalSpec has an easy to understand explanation of this on the web entitled "HEPA Filters and ULPA Filters Information."

Data:
Knowing what I know now, this is it a company I would recommend.
The HEPA filter works… probably like a lot of other HEPA filters. It says it’s good for smells and VOCs— it is not. You need 15-20lbs of activated carbon to begin to touch VOCs (like the IQAir has).
The little light will change with cooking, any kind of spray or powder in the air… but the real air quality concerns are happening at levels the sensor can’t detect.
If you’re just looking for particulate filtering (what HEPA is good for), this is decent enough… just very overpriced compared to comparable models, which will do the same for much cheaper.
If you’re looking for something that will filter everything from viruses to VOCs, look into the IQAir Multigas— not cheap at all, but life-changing for folks with things like Multiple Chemical Sensitivity.
AustinAir is also known for having a good amount of carbon, for smells.
If you’re a healthy person just looking to give your air a little help, aren’t really concerned with smells or VOCs, and don’t mind over-playing, knock yourself out. Models like Winx or Caroway will do the same for cheaper.
If you actually have health concerns and have the ability to invest more elsewhere, I would do so.

Data: This is a difficult review to write - not because it doesn't serve a purpose. As an purifier it works well. You can crank it up to its highest setting and it will circulate a good amount of air and essentially clean anything that crosses its path. Also it's a fairly quiet unit even at its highest setting. But the reason I'm giving this purifier 3 stars and nothing higher is because it's main feature of having an automatic sensor is dismal in performance and an afterthought at best. Initially I purchased this unit for my dining room/kitchen area which is roughly 350 square feet combined. I noticed upon purchasing the unit that the only time the purifier would change speeds and LED colors was when powering the unit up, otherwise it would remain "blue" and in low setting. This was also upon un-boxing it where most times the air would be more polluted. Sure enough it did nothing. I tried cleaning the air sensor on the side of the unit and that too had little effect. I then called up the company which ran me through a battery of test (lighting a match next to the sensor and blowing smoke towards it - didn't know it also functioned as a fire alarm) which of course had no effect as well. The only time it self engaged was when I pan fried hamburgers in the kitchen and even then it was a good 10 minutes after cooking. I would be amiss to say it didn't work at all, just very poorly. After explaining to the customer service tech that it was malfunctioning (like another reviewer stated they tried to say it was working fine since the light changed colors upon powering it up - I vehemently denied that saying it was simply an initialization cycle and didn't prove the sensor worked in any capacity whatsoever). Finally she agreed to send a 2nd unit and a week or so later guess what....same result. Instead of fighting with customer service on receiving another defective unit I decided to keep it based on its merits of simply being a purifier. If I smell an odor in the house I simply turn it on full speed and wait a good half hour till it's no longer apparent (if you walk out of your house for a few minutes and walk back in you'll noticed the difference instead of your nose getting accustomed to any scents). This is not what's advertised but the filters on the unit seem to be of high-quality and seem fairly reputable thus far. Just don't count on the Auto feature doing much without your own intervention.

Another concern is whether at a certain point the dust/toxins, etc. begin to recirculate once the filters reach a certain level of filth. Data:
I want to like this air purifier.
The controls are easy to use, and the filters are easy to install and remove. I find the fan noise to be completely acceptable based on the amount of air this thing can move through the filters. On auto mode you can easily fall asleep with the fan noise (typically setting 1) - in fact, I think it actually helps similar to a typical room fan that provides a white noise effect to help lull you to sleep. On full blast (setting 4) it sounds like it is moving enough air to take flight.
Build quality is solid - nothing feels cheap or poorly made. Even the filters feel like they are made from sturdy materials. And I REALLY like that the filters have a notch in the bottom right corner that prevents you from inserting them incorrectly - this is a GREAT feature.
Here's what I don't like about this air purifier. While I was able to easily find a study from a seemingly "reputable" source that claimed the removal of Aerosolized SARS-CoV-2 from the air, I was able to find a TON more Facebook-mom-for-pay, completely anecdotal reviews that just throw up instant red flags. This might not be so bad if this air purifier was inexpensive, but it absolutely is not. Replacement filters are also expensive and give me a "printer ink" vibe, even if they are well made. To be fair, on the model I have the recommended replacement cycle is annual so the expense isn't completely unwarranted. I would love to see scientific, completely independent 3rd party comparisons of these air purifiers against claimed air purification criteria the manufacturer specifies. UltraHEPA doesn't really mean anything until that happens.
Recommended for overall build quality, but not for price or unconfirmed performance.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2022
Data:
We got this during fire season when the air quality is awful and it has worked WONDERS in our house. We tried a few things to see if this actually works and IT DOES! When on auto mode my husband farted Infront of it and it kicked in full blast (yes, you read that right… no shame!), it kicks in if I even light a scented candle, spray hairspray, room spray, perfume, while cooking, etc. when the light is blue meaning “good” it’s very quiet and barely noticeable. When it kicks onto red or orange it does get a bit loud but honestly I don’t mind it, it if means my air is clean.
MY ONLY CON: (even though this isn’t really an issue now since the newer models have this) it needs a control lock. We have toddlers who are FASCINATED with pushing the buttons and hearing the beeping sound and lights. I cannot get them to leave it alone. Or my cat will jump on top of it to get to the window and push buttons. I wish our model had a lock on it but I guess we will just have to upgrade to a newer one now!
The filters seem outrageously priced so we ordered replacement filters off Amazon and so far everything works just as well. I work at an HVAC company and verified with my parts manager that using generic filters would be just as efficient.
